Graphical abstract This review emphasizes DFT and AIMD based screening of anchoring materials such as doped graphene, MOFs, MXenes, and metal sulfides for effective polysulfide immobilization, offering insights into adsorption, charge transfer, and catalytic decomposition in RT Na-S batteries. Though the formation of polysulfide is desirable, as it contributes to the capacity build-up, it must not leak into the electrolyte. The loss of polysulfide causes capacity fade, a change in thelocal chemistry of the electrolyte, and anode poisoning. Constant efforts are in progress to find suitable polysulfide-absorbing materials; however, the magical polysulfide absorber is yet to be discovered or developed. Experimental methods alone often fall short in accelerating the investigations may be due to thecomplex Nature of the testing. This review focuses on the importance of computational methods, particularly density functional theory (DFT), in screening suitable polysulfide absorbers. It highlights the critical role of anchoring materials in improving Na-S battery performance, including pristine and doped graphene, metal-organic frameworks, carbon Nanofibers, vanadium disulfide, MXenes, and metal sulfides. By examining adsorption energies, charge transfer mechanisms, and catalytic properties, this review provides insights into the design of advanced materials that can effectively immobilize polysulfides and enhance battery stability. The review aims to guide future research efforts toward the development of high-performance RT Na-S batteries through a comprehensive understanding of the polysulfide-absorbing materials. Keywords Na-S battery Computational theory Polysulfide absorbing materials DFT 1 Introduction Room temperature sodium-sulfur (RT Na-S) batteries have garnered significant interest in the field of energy storage due to their potential for high energy density (1275 Wh kg−1), low cost, and abundant raw materials [1-4]. Unlike high-temperature Na-S batteries [5], RT Na-S batteries operate at ambient conditions, making them safer and more practical for widespread applications [2,6], including grid storage and mobility applications [7-9]. Additionally, utilizing sodium and sulfur, both of which are more environmentally benign compared to lithium and cobalt, makes these batteries a sustainable and cleaner alternative to the existing batteries [10]. Despite their advantages, RT Na-S batteries face significant challenges, for example sodium dendrite growth [11-13] gas evolution [14], volume change [15], sodium polysulfides shuttling and sulfur volumetric expansion [16-18] (Fig. 1a ). During the discharge process, sulfur reacts with sodium to form soluble sodium polysulfides (Na2S n , where n = 4–8) (Fig. 1b) [19]. These polysulfides can dissolve in the electrolyte and migrate to the anode, causing self-discharge and capacity fading [20,21]. The polysulfides result in the loss of active material from the cathode, reducing the battery's capacity over repeated charge/discharge cycles [22]. Sulfur also undergoes significant volume expansion (up to 170%) when it reacts with sodium to form sodium sulfide (Na2S) [23], leading to mechanical stress and potential structural failure of the cathode [24,25]. Continuous volume changes can result in cracks and fractures, compromising the cathode's integrity and performance [26]. Moreover, sulfur and its discharge products have low electrical conductivity, hindering efficient electron transport and reducing battery performance [27]. Poor conductivity limits the efficient transport of electrons within the cathode, resulting in high overpotentials, energy losses, and lower overall battery performance. To address these challenges, researchers have developed various strategies. For instance, trapping polysulfides within the cathode using porous carbon matrices [16,28], functionalized separators [9,29-31], and electrolyte additives [32-34] helps prevent their migration. Incorporating sulfur into conductive host materials such as carbon Nanofibers [35], graphene [36], or metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [26,37] accommodates volume changes and enhances electrical conductivity. Using solid-state electrolytes [2,38] or highly concentrated electrolytes [39,40] suppresses the polysulfide shuttle effect by reducing the solubility of polysulfides. Applying protective coatings on the sulfur cathode stabilizes the interface and mitigates the detrimental effects of volume expansion and polysulfide dissolution [41-43]. Experimental methods often face significant challenges in unveiling the atomic environment of the polysulfides, leading to anincomplete understanding of material behaviours and interactions. Additionally, experimental procedures can be costly and time-consuming, with difficulties in precisely controlling the test atmosphere [44]. These limitations hinder the ability to systematically explore and optimize new materials for improved battery performance. On the other hand, computational methods, particularly density functional theory (DFT) [45,46], address these shortcomings by providing detailed insights into atomic-scale interactions, adsorption energies, charge transfer mechanisms, and catalytic properties [47]. Computational methods have become invaluable tools in the field, particularly for understanding the chemical interactions of sodium polysulfides (NaPSs) at the molecular level [48] (Fig. 1c). These methods enable researchers to delve into the intricate details of NaPSs behavior, providing insights that are often challenging to obtain solely through experimental techniques. By leveraging computational techniques such as DFT and molecular dynamics (MD) simulations [49], scientists can predict how NaPSs interact with various materials used in Na-S batteries, thereby supplementing and explaining experimental results. The ability of computational methods to simulate and visualize the behavior of NaPSs offers several significant advantages [50-52]. Firstly, they allow for the screening of a wide range of materials to identify potential candidates for NaPSs anchoring, which can mitigate issues like the polysulfide shuttle effect and capacity fading. Secondly, these methods provide detailed mechanistic insights into the interactions between NaPSs and different host materials, which is crucial for designing more efficient and stable cathodes. Lastly, computational studies can guide the rational design of new materials and interfaces, accelerating the development of high-performance Na-S batteries. Despite the extensive use of computational methods, there is a noticeable gap in understanding the polysulfide in the literature: no recent reviews focus specifically on the interaction of NaPSs with various materials in RT Na-S batteries. This gap represents a significant opportunity for a comprehensive review paper that not only summarizes the current state of knowledge but also highlights the critical role of computational methods in advancing this field. In this review, we provide an overview of the computational chemistry methods used to understand the interaction of NaPSs with various anchoring materials. These materials include carbon- and phosphorus-based compounds, metal oxides, metal sulfides, Mxenes, and MOFs (Fig. 1d). This review begins with a brief introduction to theoretical methods and anoverview of the theoretical foundations of NaPSs interactions. We then highlight NaPSs adsorption on different materials based on two important interactions: dipole-dipole and Lewis acid-base interactions. Following this, we summarize the binding energies of NaPSs on anchoring materials and discuss the potential of descriptors to predict the adsorption strength and reactivity of materials. These insights will be beneficial for the future development of advanced RT Na-S batteries. The final section provides concluding remarks, encapsulating the key findings and implications for future research. 2 Computational theories in battery research 2.1 Role of density functional theory (DFT) to screen the polysulfide absorbing materials DFT is an indispensable tool for screening polysulfide-absorbing materials in sodium-sulfur (Na-S) batteries due to its ability to provide detailed insights into atomic-level interactions [53-55]. It enables the evaluation of material properties that are crucial for mitigating the polysulfide shuttle effect, such as binding energies, charge transfer mechanisms, and catalytic activity. By simulating the adsorption of sodium polysulfides (NaPSs) on various host materials, DFT can predict which materials have the strongest binding to NaPSs, thereby preventing their dissolution into the electrolyte. For example, DFT calculations can quantify the adsorption energies of NaPSs on different surfaces, such as graphene [36], doped carbon frameworks [25], MXenes [56], or transition metal sulfides [57], revealing how chemical doping or surface modifications enhance their polysulfide-binding capabilities. Furthermore, DFT allows for the exploration of charge density distributions and electronic structure changes upon polysulfide adsorption, providing insights into the electron transfer processes that facilitate the polysulfide conversion reaction [58,59]. Additionally, DFT-based studies can identify optimal materials for improving the kinetics of polysulfide conversion reactions by calculating activation barriers for the reaction pathways. A systematic screening of functional groups for functionalized Ti3C2T2 MXenes (T = H, O, F, S, Cl, Se, Te, Br, OH, and NH) was conducted for application in Li-S batteries [60]. An optimal surface termination for enhancing both solid-state and molecular Li2S2/Li2S conversion kinetics was effectively identified, with Ti3C2Se2 highlighted as a top-performing host. In another study, researchers introduced two key parameters, solvation potential (ΔP S-C ) and stabilizing potential (ΔP S-A), to evaluate polysulfide behaviour and substrate anchoring ability [61]. Results show that long-chain polysulfides (e.g., Li2S8) are more soluble due to higher ΔP S-C. Anchoring performance is assessed by comparing the binding energy of Li2S8 to various substrates against its solvation energy. Polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) shows strong anchoring (ΔP S-A = −0.168 eV), while polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) performs poorly (ΔP S-A = +0.827 eV). Effective substrates require high-electron-density sites and multiple interaction points. Screening of polymers like Polyethylene glycol (PEG), Polypyrrol (PPy), Poly vinyl alcohol (PVA), Polyaniline (PANI), and Phosphorylated chitosan (PCS) identifies PCS as the most promising candidate for polysulfide retention. The same computational strategy and insights can be analogously extended to sodium–sulfur systems, where screening of host/anchoring materials using binding energies, reaction pathways, and catalytic effects can provide predictive guidance in tailoring materials for improved NaPS anchoring and conversion. Although DFT can solve many physical and chemical property calculations, it has a fundamental limitation: the number of particles used in calculations is much smaller than in actual matter. Despite this, DFT remains a powerful tool for understanding the macroworld. By using DFT, we can predict the properties of unknown substances from basic quantum mechanical principles and explain material behaviors at the molecular level, thus guiding experimental design. 2.1.1 Binding energy For Na-S battery applications, DFT calculations typically focus on determining the adsorption energy at the interface between sodium polysulfides (NaPSs) and the host material [23]. The adsorption energy E b is calculated using the following formula E b = E total + E NaPSs - E host where E b represents the adsorption energy of the system, E total is the total energy of the model, E NaPSs is the energy of the isolated sodium polysulfides, and E host is the energy of the host material's surface. To select the crystal planes that interact with NaPSs for calculation, researchers often use transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis. These techniques help identify the most relevant surfaces of the host material that are likely to interact with NaPSs in a real battery system. This approach ensures that the DFT calculations are representative of actual material behaviors and interactions in RT Na-S batteries. 2.1.2 Density of states (DOS) DOS describes the number of electronic states that are available within a specific energy range in a material. It provides insights into the electronic structure and properties of the material [62]. In the context of battery research, especially for RT Na-S batteries, analyzing the DOS helps in understanding how electrons are distributed across different energy levels [63]. This information is vital for predicting and optimizing the electronic conductivity and reactivity of electrode materials. A high DOS at the Fermi level, for instance, indicates a high availability of electronic states for conduction, which is beneficial for the performance of battery electrodes [64]. By examining the DOS, researchers can identify materials with desirable electronic properties, aiding in the design and development of more efficient and stable battery systems. 2.1.3 Gibbs free energy (G) Gibbs free energy (G) is a thermodynamic potential that measures the maximum reversible work a system can perform at constant temperature and pressure. It's a key parameter in predicting the spontaneity of chemical reactions: a negative ΔG indicates a spontaneous process, while a positive ΔG means the process is non-spontaneous [65]. In the context of RT Na-S batteries, Gibbs free energy calculations help in understanding the energetics of reactions involving NaPSs and their interactions with the electrode materials. Calculating ΔG for these reactions provides insights into the stability and efficiency of the battery. These calculations help in evaluating the feasibility and efficiency of different reaction pathways and materials, ultimately guiding the design of high-performance Na-S batteries. 3 Conventional computational understanding Here we discuss computational approaches to study the interaction of NaPSs with anchoring materials. DFT calculations, complemented by long-range correction and solvation models, provide atomic-level insights into these interactions, crucial for designing materials that effectively anchor NaPSs and mitigate issues like the polysulfide shuttle effect. Accurate selection of density functionals, dispersion corrections, and electronic property analyses are essential for reliable results. Given the weak van der Waals (vdW) forces and the polarizable Nature of long-chain NaPSs, capturing dispersion effects is essential for reliable estimation of binding energies, interfacial configurations, and charge transfer. For example, GGA-based functionals such as PBE, when used without dispersion corrections, often underestimate adsorption energies and fail to capture physisorption contributions, leading to an inaccurate description of polysulfide confinement. On the other hand, the inclusion of DFT-D2 or D3 corrections has been shown to improve agreement with experimental trends [59,67]. 3.1 Right selection of functionals The right selection of functionals in DFT calculations is essential for accurately predicting material properties and understanding their behavior in applications like RT Na-S batteries. Functionals significantly impact energy calculations, electronic structure, structural properties, and reaction mechanisms. For instance, the Generalized Gradient Approximation (GGA) functionals, such as PBE (Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof) [68], are often used for their balance between accuracy and computational efficiency. Hybrid functionals like B3LYP [69], can provide better accuracy for certain systems but at a higher computational cost. For systems where van der Waals interactions are significant, functionals like the van der Waals density functional (vdW-DF) [70,71] or dispersion-corrected functionals (e.g., PBE-D3) are essential [72]. These functionals ensure reliable binding energy predictions between NaPSs and host materials, crucial for enhancing battery performance. Recent studies illustrate the widespread application of DFT in studying sodium NaPSs adsorption. The success and accuracy of DFT largely depend on the specific density functional employed. Jacob's ladder is a conceptual framework in DFT that categorizes functionals into classes based on their treatment of electron density gradients [73,74]. More sophisticated functionals occupy the higher rungs of Jacob's ladder, including the GGA, meta-GGA, hybrid, and double hybrid functionals [51]. Each step up the ladder typically incorporates more complex treatments of electron exchange and correlation effects. For instance, GGA functionals improve upon LDA by including electron density gradients, resulting in better accuracy for a wider range of systems. Meta-GGAs and hybrid functionals, which mix DFT with exact exchange from Hartree-Fock theory, provide further refinements [75]. However, the increase in accuracy is not systematic or guaranteed when moving to higher rungs of the ladder. This inconsistency necessitates the benchmarking of functionals against experimental data or higher-level wavefunction-based computations to ensure their reliability for specific systems. Common benchmarks include comparing computed bond lengths, bond angles, lattice parameters, and band gaps with experimental measurements. This process helps in selecting the most appropriate functional for accurately modeling a given system. The PBE-GGA functional is widely used to study the interaction of NaPSs with anchoring materials in both periodic and finite model systems [68]. However, PBE's Native capabilities are often enhanced with correctional terms to account for long-range dispersion interactions, which are crucial for accurately predicting structures and energies in adsorption studies. Dispersion-corrected functionals, such as those implementing DFT-D3 or DFT-D4 methods, are commonly integrated with PBE to better capture van der Waals forces, leading to more reliable simulation results. For cluster-based calculations Minnesota M06-2X hybrid meta-GGA functionals are frequently employed [51]. These functionals are advantageous because they include a portion of Hartree-Fock exact exchange, which improves the description of electron correlation effects. This makes them particularly useful for the structural optimization of bare NaPSs clusters, adsorbed materials, and adsorption complexes. Additionally, B3LYP and M06-2X are utilized to determine the binding energies of NaPSs adsorption, providing valuable insights into the strength and Nature of these interactions. 3.2 Dispersion corrections Dispersion corrections in theoretical calculations address the limitations of standard DFT in capturing van der Waals (vdW) forces, crucial for accurately modeling weak intermolecular interactions. These corrections are essential for systems where long-range interactions impact material properties, such as in layered materials, organic molecules, and battery interfaces. Standard DFT functionals like GGA often miss these interactions, leading to inaccuracies in binding energies and structures [76]. Dispersion-corrected functionals, such as PBE-D3 and vdW-DF2 or semi empirical correction methods (DFT-2 and DFT-3) proposed by Grimme, improve DFT calculations by incorporating these weak forces, making them vital for reliable predictions in material design and optimization, particularly for sodium-sulfur (Na-S) batteries [70,71,77]. In a report by Wang and colleagues [27], the semi-empirical DFT-D2 approach was used to examine vdW interaction corrections in total energies and atomic forces. They conducted a comprehensive global structure search for Na2S3, Na2S2, and Na2S, using the known crystal structure of Na2S4. The stable structures were selected based on their formation energies at 0 K relative to dissociation products. To assess the influence of vdW forces, they optimized these structures and calculated formation energies using both PBE and PBE-D2 functionals, see Fig. 2 . The results demonstrated that vdW interactions have a weak effect on the lattice constants of Na-S compounds, with PBE-calculated lattice constants showing good agreement with experimental values and previous work by Momida et al. [78] This suggests that for structural parameters, PBE alone may suffice without vdW corrections. However, when considering formation energies, the PBE-D2 values were found to be closer to experimental data, indicating the importance of including vdW corrections for accurate energetic predictions. 3.3 Understanding electronic properties Analyzing the electronic properties of adsorption complexes involving NaPSs and anchoring materials provides crucial insights into their interactions. Key methods such as Bader charge analysis [79] and Natural Bond Orbital (NBO) [80] analysis offer detailed perspectives on charge redistribution and orbital interactions, respectively. Bader charge analysis is widely used in periodic systems to quantify the charge density changes when NaPSs molecules adsorb onto substrates. It reveals how electrons redistribute between NaPSs and the material surface, influencing binding energies and stability. To this end, Li and co-workers [81] used DFT calculations to explore Ti2C MXenes terminated with different functional groups (O, S, N, F, Cl, Br) as dual-function materials for RT Na-S batteries. Results highlighted that surface functional groups significantly alter MXene's structural, electronic, and surface properties, influencing their interaction with sulfur-containing species. Specifically, charge density difference analysis and Bader charge calculations revealed minimal charge transfer (0.220 e) between S8 and Ti2CO2, but substantial electron transfer (0.865 to 1.406 e) from NaPSs (Na2S n species) to Ti2CO2 (Fig. 3a ). This suggests strong adsorption of NaPSs on Ti2CO2, facilitated by the formation of Na–O covalent bonds with oxygen functional groups, enhancing the material's anchoring and catalytic capabilities in Na-S batteries. In addition, the charge density difference analysis provides spatial insights into how charges redistribute upon NaPSs adsorption. It highlights regions where electron density increases or decreases, indicating areas of strong interaction and stable adsorption sites. This method is crucial for categorizing adsorption types (e.g., intact vs. destructive adsorption) and predicting the direction and extent of charge transfer processes during battery operation. DOS analysis offers a comprehensive view of the energy states within the adsorption system. It characterizes the electronic structure and conductivity potential of materials hosting NaPSs. By plotting TDOS and PDOS, researchers can pinpoint the Fermi energy levels where significant electron density changes occur, influencing the binding strength of NaPSs to the substrate. This information guides the design of materials with optimized electronic properties for efficient Na-S battery performance. To this end, the electronic properties of Nanoporous graphene (NPG) were investigated through PDOS analysis [63]. Pristine NPG exhibited a semiconductor behavior with a band gap of 0.62 eV in PBE theory, which decreased to 0.88 eV in HSE theory due to suppressed 2pz orbitals at the Dirac point, a characteristic of graphene. Doping with B, N, and O reduced the band gap to 0.42, 0.38, and 0.45 eV, respectively, enhancing carrier populations. B-doping induced p-type conductivity, while N and O doping led to n-type conductivity, shifting the Fermi energy accordingly. COOH functional groups minimally affected the band gap of NPG, preserving its electronic states due to integration into the atomic structure without inducing magnetic moments, similar to doped graphene (Fig. 3b). In addition, people used a Nano-Fe3C electrocatalyst to improve the performance of RT Na-S batteries by facilitating sodium polysulfide dredging [83]. DFT calculations revealed that after Na2S n adsorption, the electronic states of Fe in Fe3C@G became more delocalized, indicating Fe–S bond formation. The Fe3C@G maintained its high conductivity throughout the redox process, enabling rapid electron transfer and enhancing the redox kinetics of the sulfur cathodes. Researchers introduced transition-metal single-atom catalysts (SACs) on nitrogen-doped graphene (NG) to prevent the dissolution of higher-order Na2S n and enhance the kinetics of short-chain polysulfides [82]. The anchoring material (AM) must have moderate binding energies towards Na2S n and good electronic conductivity to prevent irreversible deposition of lower-order polysulfides. Detailed electronic structure analyses, including partial density of states (PDOS) and band structure examinations, revealed that both N-doped graphene (gN) and porous N-doped graphene (pN) displayed metallic properties due to the presence of electronic states around the Fermi level. In the case of TM@NG substrates, additional metallic states near the Fermi level were observed, primarily from TM-3d orbitals and, to a lesser extent, N-2p orbitals, which were expected to enhance the electrochemical reactions of short-chain Na2S n species. The study found that Na2S n adsorption induced a metallic character in the adsorbed system on pristine graphene, with no significant hybridization between C and Na atoms, indicating weaker chemical interactions. Both gN and pN maintained their electronic conductivity after Na2S n adsorption, with no substantial changes in their electronic structures. In TM@NG cases, electronic conductivity was also retained, and significant hybridization was observed between the 3d orbitals of TMs and the 2p orbitals of S atoms. The charge transfer from Na2S n to the substrates filled the unoccupied d orbitals of electron-deficient TMs, which correlated with increased adsorption energies (see Fig. 3c). The adsorption of Na2S n species created electronic states near the Fermi level, confirming the charge transfer from the polysulfide molecules to the substrates. Overall, the discharge process is predicted to increase the electronic conductivity of pristine graphene, while doped graphene retains its metallic characteristics. Understanding these electronic properties is crucial for developing strategies to mitigate the shuttle effect in Na-S batteries. Materials engineered to enhance charge transfer efficiency and stabilize polysulfide intermediates contribute to improved battery cycling stability and enhanced energy storage capabilities. Moreover, insights from electronic structure analyses aid in tailoring materials with specific binding affinities for NaPSs, advancing the development of next-generation energy storage technologies. 4 Understanding the sulfur clusters stable form The performance of Na-S batteries is significantly enhanced by Nanosized sodium sulfide species (NSCs). However, the stability of these clusters diminishes as their size decreases, a factor often overlooked in theoretical simulations. By combining an advanced particle swarm optimization algorithm with DFT calculations, researchers determined the phase diagram and stable structures of Na-S compounds, specifically (Na2S x ) n clusters (x = 1–8; n = 1–7) [57] (see Fig. 4a ). The formation energy of the monomer (Na2S x )1 is highly unfavorable at high Na concentrations, particularly for the unstable (Na2S)1 species. However, the stability of these clusters significantly improves with increasing size through polymerization. The hexamer (Na2S)6 is identified as a stable species based on formation energy, transferred charge, and geometry descriptors. Other sodium polysulfide compounds with high Na concentrations also return to stability when considering multimers. Adsorption studies on four carbon-based materials reveal that these multimers bind strongly, especially at higher Na concentrations, and retain their structure well post-adsorption. B-doped carbon shows the best adsorption ability, potentially mitigating the shuttle effect and enhancing electrical conductivity, thereby improving Na-S battery performance (Fig. 4b, c). Monomers with high sodium concentrations are unstable, and multimer models (dimers for Na2S5 and Na2S4, trimers for Na2S3, tetramers for Na2S2, and hexamers for Na2S1) are recommended for future simulations. Despite the structural stability of NSCs on carbon-based additives, determining actual structures during battery cycling remains challenging, necessitating further investigation into more realistic models considering electrolyte environments and strong NSC interactions (Fig. 4d, e). 5 Computational investigations of sodium polysulfide interactions and dynamics This section explores the application of advanced computational methods to understand the behavior and interactions of sodium polysulfides in battery systems. To understand the time-dependent behavior of NaPSs during electrochemical cycling, it is essential to go beyond static DFT calculations and employ dynamic simulations such as ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD). These simulations provide critical insights into diffusion pathways, intermediate stability, solvation dynamics, and the kinetics of sulfur bond-breaking/forming processes. For instance, AIMD simulations enable tracking the S–S bond evolution in real time (at picosecond scale or higher), which is vital for identifying metastable intermediates or transition states in the polysulfide conversion process [84]. Furthermore, sodium-ion mobility in different host matrices and electrolyte environments can be quantified, providing diffusion coefficients that directly relate to battery performance. By elucidating the molecular-level mechanisms governing these interactions with various material, computational insights play a crucial role in optimizing battery performance, enhancing energy storage efficiency, and mitigating issues like polysulfide dissolution and shuttle effects. 5.1 Metal organic framework (MOF) In Na-S batteries, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) serve as promising host materials for encapsulating sulfur and sodium polysulfides due to their high surface area and tunable pore structures. MOFs often contain coordinatively unsaturated sites (CUS), also known as 'open metal sites', which are formed by the presence of metal clusters with an undersupply of organic linkers or through activation processes that eliminate solvent. These CUS sites act as Lewis acid sites, facilitating the adsorption and catalysis of sodium polysulfide molecules. By immobilizing and stabilizing polysulfides, MOFs can potentially mitigate issues such as polysulfide dissolution and shuttle effects in Na-S batteries, thereby improving their efficiency and cycle life. Theoretical calculations were conducted to gain atomic-level insights into the confinement of polysulfides on Ni-MOF-2D [84]. The AIMD simulations revealed that the adsorption energy (E a) increased with the length of the Na2S n chain, with values of approximately −4.4 eV for Na2S, −4.0 eV for Na2S2, −3.9 eV for Na2S3, −2.6 eV for Na2S4, and −2.5 eV for Na2S5 (Fig. 5a, b ). These high adsorption energies indicate a strong interaction between NaPSs and the Ni-MOF-2D surface, surpassing the adsorption strengths reported for other materials used with sulfur cathodes, for example, lithium. In addition, as the adsorption energies of sodium polysulfides (Na2S n ) on Ni-MOF-2D increase from Na2S5 to Na2S, the electron states of the Ni centers exhibit a notable shift. This change signifies that electron transfer from Ni to nitrogen (N) is correlated with the strengthening of the Na–N/S interaction, leading to increased adsorption energy as the polysulfide chain shortens from Na2S5 to Na2S. The strong Na–N/S interaction in Ni-MOF-2D facilitates the sodiation process from Na2S5 to Na2S during discharge and aids in the desodiation process during charging due to electron transfer from NaPSs to Ni-MOF-2D, see Fig. 5c. This dynamic electron transfer improves NaPSs sodiation-desodiation kinetics on Ni-MOF-2D. The high redox capability of Ni centers, stemming from charge redistribution in Ni-MOF-2D, enhances NaPSs adsorption and conversion, boosting discharge capacities and capacity retention. In contrast, Ni-MOF-bulk shows weak NaPSs confinement. In addition, a heterostructure of MoS2 Nanosheets on a MOF-derived N, O-codoped flower-like carbon matrix (NOC) was designed as a sulfur host for RT Na-S batteries [25]. Theoretical calculations and experiments showed that O doping enhanced polarity, leading to electron transfer from MoS2 to the carbon support, which increased MoS2’s adsorption and catalytic ability to NaPSs by weakening the sodium–sulfur bonds. The NOC provided a conductive host for sulfur storage and accommodated sulfur's volume changes. MoS2 acted as an electrocatalyst, improving the polysulfide conversion reaction kinetics and reducing the shuttle effect. Theoretical analyses revealed that NOC@MoS2 exhibited higher conductivity than MoS2 alone, with electronic states crossing the Fermi level. 5.2 Modified carbon-based material Enhancing carbon materials through doping or functionalization has proven highly effective in preventing the dissolution of NaPSs. These modifications increase the polarity of the carbon surface, thereby strengthening the interaction with polar NaPSs and enhancing their anchoring capabilities. To this end, researchers prepared a 3D microporous carbon derived from coffee residue, with small sulfur molecules (S2−4) confined in slit micropores by adjusting sulfur content [85]. The carbon-sulfur composite electrode with 40% sulfur (ACC-40S) showed a one-step Na-S reaction, and in situ UV/vis spectroscopy confirmed Na2S as the only discharge product, indicating no polysulfide formation. DFT calculations using a slit micropore model showed that Na2S formation is thermodynamically feasible with appropriate micropore size. Optimized structures of Na2S and Na2S2 intercalated into bilayer graphene (simulating slit micropores) revealed that Na2S can maintain its configuration even in narrow slits less than 0.5 nm, with a minimum energy at 0.6 nm spacing, see Fig. 6a–c. For Na2S2, a larger interlayer distance (minimum energy at 0.75 nm) is required to avoid distortion. Given the micropore size distribution (dominated at 0.46 nm), Na2S2 formation is thermodynamically unlikely, aligning with experimental results. The PDOS analysis showed that Na2S in a 0.8 nm slit interacts via van der Waals forces, while in a 0.5 nm slit, Na–C and C–S bonds form, enhancing charge transfer (Fig. 6d ). The strong interaction and charge transfer improve electron conductivity and reaction efficiency, indicating that Na2S confinement in slit micropores benefits electron transfer and reaction efficiency. To understand the competing effects between N-doping and electrical conductivity of the carbon host, researchers used DFT calculations to study the interactions of different nitrogen groups with sulfur and its discharge products. Five types of structures were analyzed: pristine graphene (P-G) and four N-containing groups: pyridinic nitrogen (N-PD), pyrrolic nitrogen (N-PL), graphitic nitrogen (N-G), and pyridine N-oxide (N-PDO) [86]. The calculations showed that N-containing groups interact with sodium in sodium sulfide and short-chain polysulfides, similar to interactions seen in Li-S batteries. The most polar N-groups (N-PD, N-PL, and N-PDO) had the strongest interactions with polar discharge products. N-PDO exhibited the strongest binding with discharged species due to polar-polar interactions, followed by N-PL and N-PD with binding energies of 0.93 and 0.86 eV for Na2S, and 1.09 and 1.06 eV for Na2S2, respectively, see Fig. 7a . N-PD, N-PDO, and N-PL's polar interactions are attributed to the lone electron pairs on nitrogen or oxygen atoms and the polar N–H bond (Fig. 7b, c). In contrast, N-G, which is nonpolar, showed a preference for binding with sulfur in the charged state, with a binding energy of 0.67 eV for short-chain S3 sulfur, due to the delocalized electron in N-G enhancing the π-electron cloud. This interaction is stronger than the van der Waals interactions observed in P-G. It has been demonstrated that the TiS2/graphene heterojunction exhibits metallic conductivity and promotes electron transfer from graphene to TiS2, thereby enhancing interfacial polarity, an important parameter for anchoring sodium polysulfides during cycling [87]. Beyond anchoring, the heterojunction's role in facilitating the decomposition of the insulating discharge product, i.e., Na2S, was explored using the CI-NEB method. The results show that the migration energy barrier for Na+ ions dissociating from Na2S on the TiS2/graphene interface is 0.31 eV, which is lower than the 0.35 eV barrier on pristine TiS2 (Fig. 7d, e). This indicates that the heterostructure provides an energetically favorable pathway for Na2S decomposition. Compared to other advanced 2D catalysts such as V2C (0.19 eV), V2CO2 (0.26 eV), Ti3CNO2 (0.26 eV), and MoSe2 (0.24 eV), the TiS2/graphene heterojunction exhibits competitive performance. This reduced kinetic barrier directly contributes to lowering overpotentials and enhancing the reversibility and rate capability of Na-S batteries by accelerating Na+ transport and promoting efficient polysulfide conversion. Sajjad’s group used first-principles calculations to evaluate the performance of two-dimensional nitrogenated holey graphene (C2N) and polyaniline (C3N) as anchoring materials in Na-S batteries [88]. The study found that polar C2N outperforms nonpolar C3N in binding strength due to greater charge transfer, resulting in strong ionic binding with energies between −2.33 and −3.09 eV. While bilayer C2N slightly improves anchoring behavior, the increase in binding energies is minimal. The electron localization function (ELF) revealed that physical binding dominates during sodiation, except for Na2S adsorption on C2N, which forms a covalent bond, see Fig. 8a . Adsorption of NaPSs on C2N induces n-type doping, potentially enhancing conductivity, whereas S8 does not alter C2N's electronic properties. Additionally, NaPSs bind weakly with electrolytes like DME and DOL, suggesting limited dissolution into these solvents. This study highlights the potential of cost-effective C2N Nanosheets as anchoring materials for improving the performance of sodium-sulfur batteries. Wang and co-workers developed a high-performance RT-Na/S battery using nitrogen-doped carbon microspheres with gold Nanodots as the sulfur host [66]. The nitrogen doping and gold Nanodots enhance polysulfide adsorption via polar-polar interactions, while a thick outer shell physically confines reactions, mitigating the polysulfide shuttle effect. Gold Nanodots also act as electrocatalysts, facilitating the complete transformation of Na2S4 into Na2S, thus improving sulfur cathode reactivity and capacity. The calculated binding energies of S8, Na2S4, Na2S3, Na2S2, and Na2S on nitrogen-doped carbon are −0.03, −0.32, −0.78, −1.10, and −0.93 eV, respectively. See Fig. 8b. When loaded with gold nanodots, these values significantly improve to −1.63, −2.97, −3.06, −3.52, and −3.94 eV, respectively, indicating much stronger interactions that prevent polysulfide shuttling. Free energy calculations demonstrated that the conversion of S8 to Na2S is more energetically favorable on gold-loaded carbon, lowering energy barriers and enhancing battery performance, see Fig. 8c. These improvements make CN/Au/S a promising cathode material for high-performance RT-Na-S batteries suitable for large-scale energy storage. A 3D “branch-leaf” biomimetic design was proposed by Du’s group for high-performance Na-S batteries [90]. The “leaves,” made from Co Nanoparticles on carbon Nanofibers (CNF), fully expose Co's active sites, while the CNF network acts as conductive “branches” ensuring electron and electrolyte supply. This design forms a conductive network with abundant active sites and voids, effectively trapping polysulfides and providing ample pathways for electron/ion transport during electrochemical reactions. DFT calculations show that Co Nanoparticles form a unique Co–S–Na molecular layer on their surface, enabling fast polysulfide reduction. Researchers have developed atomically dispersed nitrogen and sulfur-coordinated iron (Fe) catalysts embedded in porous carbon Nanofibers (SA Fe-N/S@CNF) for RT Na-S batteries [89]. The second-shell sulfur atoms modulate the electronic structure of Fe centers, enhancing catalytic activity and ensuring dendrite-free sodium deposition. The absorption energies of S8 and polysulfide species on SA Fe-N/S@CNF, SA Fe-N@CNF, and CNF surfaces were calculated, see Fig. 8d, showing that SA Fe-N/S@CNF offers moderate bonding energies, which are crucial for maintaining catalytic efficiency and preventing fast capacity decay. The Gibbs free energy (ΔG) values for polysulfide conversion on these matrices reveal that SA Fe-N/S@CNF has the lowest ΔG, indicating favorable thermodynamics and superior catalytic performance, see Fig. 8e. AIMD simulations confirmed the stability of S8 anchoring on SA Fe-N/S@CNF, even at high temperatures, demonstrating its stability during electro-catalysis, see Fig. 8f. Reduced density gradient analysis showed that van der Waals interactions between the adsorbed S8 and second-shell S atoms ensure appropriate polysulfide adsorption and promote conversion kinetics, see Fig. 8g. This research highlights the potential of SA Fe-N/S@CNF as an effective sulfur carrier for high-performance sodium-sulfur batteries. 5.3 Metal sulfides and nitrides In addition to carbon materials, a variety of metal sulfides and nitrides serve as effective polar hosts in sulfur cathodes, demonstrating robust interactions with NaPSs to mitigate the shuttle effect. Researchers synthesized sulfur-doped graphene frameworks with atomically dispersed 2H-MoS2 and single Mo atoms (S@MoS2-Mo1/SGF) [91], achieving a high sulfur mass loading of 80.9 wt.% for RT-Na/S battery cathodes. Calculations showed that the adsorption energies of Na2S4, Na2S3, Na2S2, and Na2S on S@MoS2-Mo1/SGF were –4.67, –8.66, –10.66, and –14.66 eV, respectively, indicating a smooth discharge process, see Fig. 9a . In comparison, S@MoS2/SGF and SGF had significantly higher adsorption energies, implying difficulty in progressing beyond Na2S4. AIMD simulations reflected more realistic conditions, confirmed these findings. S@MoS2-Mo1/SGF exhibited a large negative adsorption energy (∼–12 eV) over 5 ps, while S@MoS2/SGF and SGF faced positive energy barriers (∼6 eV), hindering the discharge process (Fig. 9b). The final structure of S@MoS2-Mo1/SGF favored the Na2S intermediate, whereas S@MoS2/SGF and SGF favored Na2S3 and Na2S4, respectively. These results highlight the superior performance of S@MoS2-Mo1/SGF in facilitating the complete discharge reaction in RT Na/S batteries. First-principles DFT was utilized to investigate the suppression of the polysulfide shuttle using 2D As2S3 as a cathode additive [58]. The study demonstrated that 2D As2S3 effectively inhibits the dissolution of polysulfide intermediates in common electrolytes due to its stronger binding energy with polysulfides compared to that of the electrolytes (Fig. 9c, d). This strong binding effectively suppresses the shuttle effect, a common issue in Na-S batteries where polysulfides dissolve and migrate between electrodes, causing capacity loss and reduced efficiency. The suppression mechanism is facilitated by electron transfer from the unfilled S-3p states of polysulfides to the As2S3 layer, enhancing polysulfide adsorption on the anchoring layer. This electron transfer process also reduces the band gap of As2S3, which in turn increases its conductivity, as conductivity is inversely related to the band gap (σ ∝ exp(−E g/kBT)). Consequently, the incorporation of As2S3 not only mitigates the shuttle effect but also improves the conductivity of the cathode, leading to enhanced cycling stability and Coulombic efficiency of the battery. Jayan et al. investigated single-layer vanadium disulfide (VS2) as an anchoring material for Na-S batteries using DFT calculations [59]. They found that VS2 binds Na2S n species strongly, with adsorption energies ranging from 0.4 to 4.31 eV, without causing structural distortion (Fig. 9e). VS2's binding energies for soluble polysulfides are higher than those of common solvents (DOL and DME), effectively immobilizing polysulfides. Chemical interactions dominate for lower-order Na2S n species, while vdW interactions are significant for higher-order ones. Bader charge analysis, charge density difference analysis, and PDOS reveal strong chemical bonding and significant charge transfer from Na2S n to VS2. The metallic Nature of VS2 is retained after adsorption, improving electrochemical reaction kinetics. Additionally, the low Gibbs free energy barrier for sulfur reduction reaction and decomposition energy barrier for Na2S oxidation ensure efficient sulfur utilization, see Fig. 9f. These findings provide insights for designing high energy density, long-life Na-S batteries with VS2. Researchers designed hollow, polar, catalytic bipyramid prisms of cobalt sulfide (p-CoS2) as an efficient sulfur host for Na-S batteries [92]. The structure of p-CoS2 features interwoven surfaces and spacious internal voids to accommodate NaPSs and manage volumetric expansion. DFT calculations show that the formation energies of NaPSs bound to p-CoS2 (100) are significantly lower than those bound to nonpolar graphene or in a “liquid” state, see Fig. 10a . This strong binding is due to charge transfer between Co2+ sites on p-CoS2 and S atoms in NaPSs, with binding strength increasing as NaPS chain length decreases. This enhanced interaction supports better performance and stability for Na-S batteries. The study reveals that charge transfer occurs from surface S atoms to Na in the Na2S4 cluster, leading to strong chemical interactions. One terminal S atom in Na2S4 forms a stable octahedral (CoS6) environment by interacting with a square pyramidal (CoS5) Co2+ site on the p-CoS2 surface. This interaction involves charge transfer from Co to S, further enhancing the stability and effectiveness of p-CoS2 as a sulfur host in Na-S batteries (Fig. 10b). People conducted first-principles theory calculations to investigate the use of transition metal-N4@graphene (with metals Fe, Co, and Mn) as multifunctional anchoring materials to mitigate the “shuttling effect” of NaPSs in Na-S batteries [36]. The results revealed that doping graphene with metal-N4 significantly improves electronic conductivity and enhances adsorption of Na2S n species and cyclo-S8 due to strong metal–S and N–Na chemical bonds, see Fig. 10c. Among the metals studied, Fe-N4 co-doped graphene exhibited the best performance as an anchoring material. The electrocatalytic properties of Fe-N4@graphene were further analyzed using the climbing image nudged elastic band (ci-NEB) method. The findings showed that iron doping substantially lowers the decomposition energy barriers of Na2S by 0.89 eV and Na2S2 by 0.18 eV, enhancing sulfur utilization and battery discharge capacity (Fig. 10d–g). These insights advance the understanding of metal-N4@graphene as effective anchoring materials for sulfur electrodes and aid in designing high-performance Na-S batteries. 5.4 Two-dimensional transition metal carbides/nitrides (MXenes) It has been discovered that 2D layered transition metal carbides and nitrides (MXenes), as polar materials, are effective adsorbents of NaPSs. They exhibit strong interactions with NaPSs, thereby immobilizing the soluble NaPSs and preventing their shuttling effect. DFT calculations were employed to investigate the bifunctionality of Ti2C MXenes terminated with various functional groups (O, S, N, F, Cl, and Br) as both anchoring materials and electrocatalysts for Na-S batteries [81]. The study found that the type of surface functional group significantly influences the structural, electronic, and surface properties of MXenes, impacting their interaction with sulfur-containing species. Among the six MXenes analyzed, Ti2CO2, Ti2CS2, and Ti2CN2 demonstrated significantly stronger binding capabilities with NaPSs compared to those terminated with halogen functional groups and organic electrolytes. This indicates their effectiveness as anchoring materials for Na-S batteries. The study also elucidated that van der Waals (vdW) interactions primarily dominated the adsorption of S8 on MXenes, while chemical interactions played a key role in the confinement of NaPSs (see Fig. 11a ). Additionally, Ti2CO2, Ti2CS2, and Ti2CN2 exhibited excellent catalytic performance in the sodium polysulfide redox reactions and the decomposition of Na2S, while also facilitating Na ion migration on their surfaces. Importantly, these MXenes maintained their metallic conductivity throughout the entire discharge process, which is advantageous for improving sulfur utilization and accelerating the kinetically slow redox reactions. In addition, research suggests that functionalized MXenes, specifically Hf3C2T2 and Zr3C2T2 (T = F, O), can serve as effective cathode additives to mitigate the shuttle effect in Na-S batteries [56]. The binding energies of NaPSs on these MXenes are stronger than those with common electrolytes like DOL and DME, see Fig. 11b, c. Oxygen-functionalized MXenes exhibit a greater chemical binding effect on polysulfides, reducing the shuttle effect during discharge and lowering the activation energy during charge. Bader analysis shows significant charge transfer from Na2S n to MXenes, particularly with oxygen passivation, indicating stronger binding energies. Another group explored the catalytic role of MXene in enhancing sodium-ion diffusion and facilitating the decomposition of Na2S by CI-NEB calculations [56]. The study examined two MXene structures, Hf3C2O2 and Zr3C2O2, focusing on the dissociation of Na2S into NaS and Na+ (Na2S → NaS + Na+ + e−), followed by Na+ ion migration along two different diffusion paths. For Hf3C2O2, the energy barriers were calculated to be about 1.28 and 1.42 eV (Fig. 11d, e), while Zr3C2O2 exhibited slightly higher barriers of 1.32 and 1.57 eV (Fig. 11f, g), respectively. These values are significantly lower than those of isolated Na2S, indicating that both MXenes lower the kinetic barrier for Na2S decomposition and promote Na+ mobility. Notably, the dissociation was found to be spontaneous on both surfaces, requiring no energy absorption. Compared to other reported materials such as single-layer VS2 (0.53 eV) [59], Cr@N-doped graphene (1.54 eV) [82] and Fe–N4@graphene (1.05 eV) [36] the MXenes show competitive catalytic performance. These findings suggest that Hf3C3O3 and Zr3C2O2 can effectively accelerate the decomposition of Na2S and facilitate fast Na+ diffusion, thereby improving the reversibility and kinetics of redox reactions in room-temperature sodium–sulfur batteries. 5.5 Monolayers Monolayers, such as Janus MSX monolayers play a crucial role in addressing the challenges posed by NaPSs in Na-S batteries [48]. These materials provide enhanced adsorption and strong chemical interactions with NaPSs, effectively immobilizing them and reducing the shuttle effect. Their high surface area and abundant active sites enable better catalytic activity, promoting efficient redox reactions. Unlike lithium systems, sodium-based reactions involve different intermediate species, larger ionic radii, and weaker binding interactions, which require tailored theoretical models. Through simulations, researchers can evaluate key descriptors such as adsorption energy of polysulfides on host materials, Na-ion migration barriers, the stability of intermediate species (e.g., Na2S x ), and electronic conductivity. These parameters are crucial for identifying materials that can stabilize polysulfides, catalyze redox reactions, and maintain structural integrity during cycling. Recent theoretical advancements have also focused on understanding the multifunctional role of host materials. For instance, dual-functional hosts capable of both physical confinement and chemical interaction with sodium polysulfides are being studied by modeling surface reactivity and electronic structures. The interplay between mechanical properties and electrochemical performance is another emerging direction, particularly important for designing interphases and flexible cathodes that can withstand volume changes. Looking forward, integrating high-throughput computational screening and machine learning (ML) with conventional DFT approaches offers a promising pathway to accelerate materials discovery. By leveraging large datasets and predictive algorithms, it becomes feasible to map a vast chemical space of sulfur hosts, additives, and electrolyte combinations, rapidly identifying optimal candidates without exhaustive experimental testing. Recent advances have demonstrated the potential of integrating deep learning with descriptor-based screening to accelerate the discovery of high-performance catalysts for RT Na-S batteries. In particular, natural language processing (NLP) (Fig. 15a, b ) and large language models (LLMs) have been employed to analyze chemical embeddings of single-atom catalysts by comparing them across domains [102]. This text-mining approach enabled the identification of promising elements, analogous material systems, and strategic design principles relevant to sulfur reduction reactions. Subsequently, electronic descriptors such as the d-band centre derived from DFT simulations were used to validate and refine the candidate catalysts. Among these, a Co-N/S single-atom configuration emerged as an effective catalytic site for facilitating polysulfide conversion (Fig. 15c–f). This data-driven methodology not only enhances the mechanistic understanding of electrocatalysis in Na-S systems but also provides a scalable framework for intelligent catalyst screening. Such hybrid approaches are poised to play a critical role in the rational design of future electrode materials and electrolyte interfaces in next-generation sodium-sulfur batteries. In addition, the development of multiscale models, which bridge atomic-level phenomena with device-level performance, is expected to play a central role in translating theoretical insights into practical battery design. These models can simulate real-world conditions, such as temperature variation, current load, and long-term cycling, providing guidance for system-level optimization. By offering mechanistic clarity, predictive design, and accelerated screening capabilities, these tools not only complement experimental efforts but also pave the way for rational development of next-generation Na-S batteries. His research focuses on the scale-up of Zn–MnO2 pouch cells for stationary grid energy storage applications. coredata.dc:description: Though the formation of polysulfide is desirable, as it contributes to the capacity build-up, it must not leak into the electrolyte. The loss of polysulfide causes capacity fade, a change in thelocal chemistry of the electrolyte, and anode poisoning. Constant efforts are in progress to find suitable polysulfide-absorbing materials; however, the magical polysulfide absorber is yet to be discovered or developed. Experimental methods alone often fall short in accelerating the investigations may be due to thecomplex Nature of the testing. This review focuses on the importance of computational methods, particularly density functional theory (DFT), in screening suitable polysulfide absorbers. It highlights the critical role of anchoring materials in improving Na-S battery performance, including pristine and doped graphene, metal-organic frameworks, carbon Nanofibers, vanadium disulfide, MXenes, and metal sulfides. By examining adsorption energies, charge transfer mechanisms, and catalytic properties, this review provides insights into the design of advanced materials that can effectively immobilize polysulfides and enhance battery stability. The review aims to guide future research efforts toward the development of high-performance RT Na-S batteries through a comprehensive understanding of the polysulfide-absorbing materials.
